posts.name: Yoav
posts.cooked: How to connect properly two usb cameras to the raspberry pi and read images from both of them in the raspberry pi code that is written in python?
You just have to grab two sources and generate two data streams, robotpy, wpilibs java and cpp libraries and basic opencv will support this

posts.name: Sahar
posts.cooked: Can you give example code please?
I could give a java example right now or if you’d like a can go write it up in python in about 10 minutes

posts.name: Yoav
posts.cooked: We will wait for the python example. Thank you very much
No problem I’ll have it typed up soon

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Are you using the WPILibPi image?  If so, you can start from the Python example it includes and follow the RobotPy-cscore documentation for image processing (or if you aren’t just use RobotPy-cscore directly). Custom Image processing — RobotPy 2023 documentation

posts.name: Sahar
posts.cooked:
I used your code in my python file and this happend:

CS: WARNING: USB Camera 1: could not set format 1 res 320x240 (UsbCameraImpl.cpp:973)

CS: ERROR: ioctl VIDIOC_G_PARM failed at UsbCameraImpl.cpp:990: Inappropriate ioctl for device (UsbUtil.cpp:156)

CS: ERROR: ioctl VIDIOC_REQBUFS failed at UsbCameraImpl.cpp:654: Invalid argument (UsbUtil.cpp:156)

CS: WARNING: USB Camera 1: could not allocate buffers (UsbCameraImpl.cpp:655)

Someone knows what’s the problem?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: What USB cameras are you using?  You can use v4l2-utils to get more information; what does v4l2-ctl -d 1 —list-formats say?

posts.name: Sahar
posts.cooked: Each camera separately is working fine. But when I’m trying to capture both cameras in parallel I got this error…

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Sometimes one camera will create two video devices, so the “second” camera may actually be trying to connect to the second device of the first camera.  E.g. the first camera appears as both /dev/video0 and /dev/video1, and you’re trying to connect to devices 0 and 1.  How are you specifying the video devices to capture (device number, path?)?  What does v4l2-ctl --list-dev output?

posts.name: Sahar
posts.cooked:
v4l2-ctl --list-dev bcm2835-codec-decode (platform:bcm2835-codec): /dev/video10 /dev/video11 /dev/video12 /dev/video18 /dev/video31 /dev/media3

bcm2835-isp (platform:bcm2835-isp): /dev/video13 /dev/video14 /dev/video15 /dev/video16 /dev/video20 /dev/video21 /dev/video22 /dev/video23 /dev/media1 /dev/media2

rpivid (platform:rpivid): /dev/video19 /dev/media0

HD Camera (usb-0000:01:00.0-1.3): /dev/video0 /dev/video1 /dev/media4

Microsoft® LifeCam HD-3000: Mi (usb-0000:01:00.0-1.4): /dev/video2 /dev/video3 /dev/media5

pi@wpilibpi(rw):~ ^C
pi@wpilibpi(rw):~ pi@wpilibpi(rw):~$ v4l2-ctl --list-dev bcm2835-codec-decode (platform:bcm2835-codec): /dev/video10 /dev/video11 /dev/video12 /dev/video18 /dev/video31 /dev/media3

bcm2835-isp (platform:bcm2835-isp): /dev/video13 /dev/video14 /dev/video15 /dev/video16 /dev/video20 /dev/video21 /dev/video22 /dev/video23 /dev/media1 /dev/media2

rpivid (platform:rpivid): /dev/video19

this is the output.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
Yep, that’s exactly what’s happening, see:

and

So you need to be connecting to devices 0 and 2, not devices 0 and 1.

posts.name: Sahar
posts.cooked: Thank you very much, I will check it

posts.name: Sahar
posts.cooked:
I changed to 0 and 2 and that happened:

CS: USB Camera 0: Connecting to USB camera on /dev/video0

[ WARN:0@0.286] global /pi-gen/work/WPILibPi/stage3/rootfs/usr/src/opencv-4.6.0/modules/videoio/src/cap_gstreamer.cpp (862) isPipelinePlaying OpenCV | GStreamer warning: GStreamer: pipeline have not been created

[ WARN:0@0.286] global /pi-gen/work/WPILibPi/stage3/rootfs/usr/src/opencv-4.6.0/modules/videoio/src/cap_v4l.cpp (902) open VIDEOIO(V4L2:/dev/video0): can’t open camera by index

[ WARN:0@0.289] global /pi-gen/work/WPILibPi/stage3/rootfs/usr/src/opencv-4.6.0/modules/videoio/src/cap_gstreamer.cpp (862) isPipelinePlaying OpenCV | GStreamer warning: GStreamer: pipeline have not been created

Only one camera is working, while the other is not…

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: That’s odd, it shouldn’t be using gstreamer at all.  Please share your source code? (use``` here, or create a gist, so it’s readable)

posts.name: Sahar
posts.cooked: The source code: (python)

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Okay, you’re using opencv instead of cscore to access the cameras… actually you’re using both; CameraServer.startAutomaticCapture() also opens /dev/video0, which is what you’re also trying to do with cv2.VideoCapture(0), so the two are conflicting. I would recommend you just use cscore:
